I wanted a pocket sized screwdriver with a few different bits to carry around when I'm working. Couldn't find what I want, have printer, enjoy technical modeling. So I figured I had no choice but to make my own. It's built for the 4x28mm bits you'd find in many of the small multi-bit sets most of you probably already have.

This prints very well with supports on an FFF printer. Feel free to tweak and redistribute as you see fit. Many thanks to everyone before me who have tackled all the scad formulas that got me started.

I bought a Popsocket and a stand that attaches to a wall or car and it works fantastic, but I needed just a stand for my phone after installing the Popsocket for when I didn't want it attached to a wall or in my car.

title: Welding glass camera holder for eclipse

description.text:
A quick mod of tteeddd's ND filter. I changed the size of the ring to clip onto my Fuji 18-135 WD lens (67mm filter ring size). I removed the Nikon filter hood mount in favor of a straight cylinder. It doesn't fit into the hood bayonet mount, but it clicks over it good enough to stay still on a tripod. Probably only good for a days use if the plastic wears from friction, luckily there's only one of these eclipses for a while.

I added an arm at the top if you want to use a rubber band or something to help mount it.

I also sized it up to fit a welding lens that I got at a TSC store http://www.tscstores.com/HOBART-10-SHADE-LENS-P2027.aspx#.WZcEGyiGNaQ

title: Armattan Chameleon Rear VTX/RX Antenna Mount w/Battery Protector

description.text: This is a CENTER mount for your VTX pigtail. You use TWO - 20mm long standoffs in lieu of the Chameleon rear vtx brace. This mount accepts standard pigtail connectors and mounts it at a 60 degree angle and gives some cushion for your antennas. Also is a rear battery protector sleeve that keeps up to a 1500mah in place and prevents rear prop strikes due to your battery shifting on a crash. I have tested these prints and they work perfectly. Pictured is an Indestructible Quads 1500mah Black Label Battery for sizing.

EDIT 8-Jan-2018: Added STL files for a smaller box, with bottom pieces to fit a quarter-sized Perma-Proto board, a Radio Shack 276-159B proto board, or an Adafruit Huzzah board. Also tweaked the pins to make them easier to print.

This box fits the half- or quarter-size Adafruit Perma-Proto board, a printed circuit board that duplicates the layout of a standard breadboard so that it's easy to make a permanent version of your prototype project without redesign.

It requires two 1/4" #4-40 screws to attach the board to the standoffs. I think 5mm M3x .5 would be the metric equivalent. Or you could integrate snap-in standoffs using this library - I'd like to see that.

The top attaches to the bottom with printed pins, though they may not be needed depending on how tight the top fits for you, or how loose the side panels are.

The open-frame + panel design makes it really easy to get your hands into, easy to customize the panels for panel-mounting components (using OpenSCAD, other software, or machining other materials), and looks decent - there are no externally-visible fasteners.

The left panel has a bracket to fit a slide-in RJ11 jack, which my project needed. If you don't need that, just print two of the right panel.

The OpenSCAD source is included. The most up-to-date source is at GitHub, and you'll also need my OpenSCAD library.

To change the size, edit side_panel_box.scad. To modify the panels, edit final_box.scad. There's a ton of other goodies in this project that I'll post as separate Things.

The pins came from Emmett. Thanks, Emmett!

author: SheepsFeaTheR

description.text: Simple Single Round Mag - way cheaper to print than buying a $65 multishot mag replacement. If you have feedback, let me know.

Small update
I added a video showing its strength against shaking and mounted on a mini bike. It actually didn't slip down at all if i attached it up further than i wanted and than slid it down into position. I will still make a better way to hold it in position sometime soon.

(LInk so it appears at the top https://youtu.be/rCnbRJnBmYA)

This is a phone holder i made to be used on a bike or motorcycle. It ended up being a little bigger and heavier than i hoped but it still works good, the phone won't come loose no matter how hard i shake it, even with weak rubber bands. To attach it to the bike i strapped it on with zip ties and an anti slip mat.

The largest phone in the pictures is 6'' long and all the pictures are with the long plate size (there is a spacer in the middle because the short is too small for my phone). The small phone is 4.5 inches long (the short one would fit it well). The PlateShortV2 may be the best for any phone.

Hardware information:

All bolts are 1/4 inch (the holes are 7mm and the nut holes are 12mm across the flat side.)

1 1/2 inch - 7x (for the top holders and one for the middle)
1 inch - 2x (for the sides of the mount. In the pictures i used 1 1/2 inch and they are too long.)
1/2 - 2x (to connect the middle. Can use zip ties instead)
Nuts - 11x
5 rubber bands

The only thing that needs supports is the arm bottom. The top holders should be printed in the orientation they are in.

The arm zip is part of an arm i planed on making but it ended up to heavy to work right. it can still be used to angle the phone different. The gear in the arm is from here. In the future i plan on making a better version with an extended arm but that might be a while from now.

author: houska34

title: Compact universal filament spool holder (Fully printable)

description.text:
A fully 3D-printable standalone filament spools holder:

  • Universal- for every spools size and type.
  • Best bearings imitation- smooth move.
  • Minimization of storage space (when disassembled).
  • Fully printable! No bearings, no glue etc. (there is place for screws but they aren't necessary).

I made it because every design I found doesn't meet my requirements. They need bearings or printable bearing imitations doesn't give smooth move. Another design works well but are BIG - toooo big. Another models use 3d printer parts as construction (stand) - it deforming 3D printer construction in my opinion. Many models doesn't predict that if radius of spool is bigger you need to increase wheel distance to make it stabile.
So in my design I try to solve all this problems.

INSTRUCTION:

  1. SCREW NOT NESSESERY! - I made place for it because I predict that in special cases stand would flip.
  2. PIVOT HOLE SIZE - pivot is piece of filament - holes are made for 4 MM filament but I think it could work with smaller. If necessary of course you can modify the model. If you do that - please send me it - I will add it for everyone.
  3. It is possible that you will need to MANUALLY improve holes size like in my cases. I made it by drill.
    ENJOY!

title: Magnet/Pin Capillary Holder for ANL Advanced Photon Source SBC X-Ray Crystallography Beam-line Prep (Parametric)

description.text:
This is a design intended for the Structural Biology Center (SBC) at the Advanced Photon Source (APS) at Argonne National Lab (ANL) as a mount for x-ray crystallography.

It is parametrized, so if you find the tolerances or exact size doesn't fit your specific magnet or pin, just change the parameters a bit in the OpenSCAD file. OpenSCAD is a free, pretty lightweight software, so you can change the file pretty easily if needed.

Use your printing software to find out the last layer where the top is open and pause the print on that layer. Once paused, push the magnet into place and then continue print (as seen in image 5)

This can be printed with or without the groove.

This can also be printed with an open bottom so you can push in the magnet from the bottom. If you want this, turn "Embedded" to false. If you do this, you may still want to stop the print and place the magnet in place as a way to hold up the plastic, as most printers can't print a flat cover over an empty cylinder hole. You may also want to make the MagnetShellRadiusTol a bit bigger to be able to slide in and out the magnet. With default settings it is pretty snug.

PRO-TIPS:
-Use your software to manually move the print head away from the print when it is paused so you do not melt the print.
-Keep the magnet on the print-bed so it heats up and can be printed on more easily
-My printer struggled to print onto the magnet, so be prepared to stick a poker of some sort (I used metal forceps) to squish down the hot plastic over the magnet for the first couple layers over it. This will likely mess up your groove, so you may want to set "Groove" to "false".

title: Bottle Fly Trap for Mason Jars
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Fill 1/3 of the jar with water and a add a scrap of raw fish or raw meat. Screw the cone or tubes part in with the lid ring, them pop the top cover into the four small holes.
Within a few days, as the meat decomposes, the flies will start filling your trap! White plastic seems to work best since the flies are attracted to light and will head up to the underside of the cover and not the light shining through the holes. The top cover stops rain from filling the jar.

Pictured is my cone trap after only a week or two. And, yes, that is nearly a full quart of green bottle flies! Gross!

This is for wide-mouth Mason jars. I have included the JSCAD file in case you want to adapt it for small-mouth jars.

This is best printed in ABS or other heat tolerant plastic if you live in a hot area or put it in direct sunlight.

Printer:

ANet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

comments.text:
I live out in Amish country and my house fills up with flies fairly regularly. I need something like this!
I know that raw meat would be a VERY effective bait, but is there something better suited for indoor use without my house smelling like carrion?
comments.author: twofourfresh

comments.text: I use this trap with rotten meat to catch bottle flies, those shiny green monsters that pester our urban chickens. If you have houseflies, you would want to use a different bait, probably something sweet like sugar water with a little spoiled fruit. Your best bet is to watch for what they are most attracted to and use that, making sure what ever it is that attracts them is only available from the trap by keeping other sources cleaned up and stored away.

title: Wanhao Duplicator 6 Raspberry Pi camera holder

description.text:
This part will allow you to mount a raspberry pi camera at extruder level to see what's going on with your printer. Perfect for Octoprint and the like.

It mounts to the top cable holder bolt on the left side of the printer. The cables are held in place by the camera holder so you don't need to use the plastic loop that is installed from factory.
I advise adding an M4 washer between the printed part and the mounting nut to spread the load and prevent damage to the printed part.

You'll also need two M2 nuts, bolts and washers, with at least 12mm thread length. I used longer ones and cut them down once it was screwed together.
Also, you'll need a longer camera cable to reach your Raspberry Pi, which can be found on ebay and the like in various lengths.

The lens hood is used to prevent the LED's from causing lens flare and is super glued into place, but only AFTER focusing the camera. My Raspberry Pi camera V2 came with a focusing tool so it was easy to do.
Play with the focus to get a good image (I moved the extruder just beyond halfway across the print bed and focused the camera there).

On the subject of LED's, the more light the better. You'll have better image quality and less motion blur.
I added 24V LED strips to three sides of my printer, totaling about 1 amp worth of power draw and it works well.

There is a little hole in the front of the case. It lines up with an LED that was on one of my cameras, so you can drill it out to size and stick some plastic rod or thick fishing line or something to act as a light pipe so you can see if the LED is on.

I've supplied STEP and Rhino 3D (.3dm) files so you can remix and stuff if needed. Just be cool and credit me somehow. :)

title: Burley Travoy compatible luggage clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is my first successful modeling + printing project. It's a test of a 3d printed luggage clip for my new Burley Travoy bike trailer. Right now it just has a circle through it, possibly for a bungee or a carabiner, but mostly I just wanted to prove that I could model and print something myself and at the same time see if a 3d printed thing at 10% infill would be strong enough to do the job here. I'll probably print at 30, 60 and 100% if each one fails, but who knows. If I ever get a functional one that's strong enough, I'll remix this to have a cable strap of some kind.

comments.text: nice clean design. What program did you use to create it?
comments.author: freddotu

comments.text: Hmm, apparently that part of what I typed got eaten.  I modeled this in Fusion360, and I have the Monoprice Maker Ultimate, which could print in ABS but would do better with it if it were enclosed.  I'm not a big fan of saying, "oh such and such is stronger" since I mostly care if things are strong enough for my application specifically without worrying about being as strong as it's possible to be.  I was able to break this part as printed, but only by going way outside of the normal way that it will experience force.  I'm going to bump it up to 20% infill as part of the "normal print" profile, and I'll print 3 of them this time so I can destructively test another one but still have two that are usable with my Surly Junk Strap.

remixed_from.title: Custom Ducting for Node 202 Case and EVGA ACX 3 Graphics

title: Fractal Design Node 202 GPU Fan Duct

description.text:
This is a modification to manypopes excellent work on a GPU fan duct for the Fractal Designs Node 202 case. These work great for keeping the GPU cool with fresh air, and keeping the recirculated air in the case cooler. Where previously I had to reduce power to 85% to avoid hitting thermal limits on a benchmark, I can now crank it up to 120% power with a 100/350 overclock and still not hit thermal limits.

Many many thanks to manypopes who did the really hard CAD work.

Modifications I made:
-Increased the height and added a soft, compliant conical flange to the top to fit around the GPU fan rims. The GPU presses on these slightly to make a seal.
-Modified the position of the ducts slightly (1 mm) to better match my GPU (also an EVGA, so I suspect they use the same design)
-Modified the duct geometry to have a more consistent wall thickness. This was difficult to do with the full size case cutout, so I modified that to just the largest inscribed circle I could fit. I tried thinner walls than this to save time and filament, but it didn't print well with such a steep wall slope, so this was my final iteration: 2 mm at the base, 1 mm at the tip, tapered to 0.4 mm at the tip of the flange.
-Updated the screw hole bosses to be just sufficient to grab and hold a standard case fan screw.
-Thinned down the base plate, again to save filament.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Your choice.

Infill:

Doesn't matter much with such thin walls.

Notes:

I used black ABS
105C Bed temp
235C Extruder Temp
I used a 2mm brim, but it is such a large, thin, base that it's not necessary if you have decent adhesion. I just like the brim because it shows me if I have problems before the print really starts.

author: pitboss8881

description.text:
Could there be anything more fun than drawing 3D surface plots? Yes, you can 3D print 3D surface plots and hold them in your own hands!  (Indeed, I wrote this OpenSCAD program in 2011 for a math teacher who wanted some tangible 3D plots for a blind student.)
And, it would be REALLY COOL to mod this somehow for dualstrusion to produce AWESOME contour plots.  For example, print every fifth layer in a contrasting color.  The one in the photo was done manually using the Jetty Firmware's "Pause at Z-height" and changing out the filament in a single extruder.
At any rate, be the first carbon-based life unit on your block with a Lego(tm) set which includes
z(x,y) = cos(sqrt(x^2+y^2))/(1+x^2+y^2)
Or, print your own doll house washboard with
z(x,y) = cos(|x|+|y|).

• Download the attached OpenSCAD program, 3dplot.scad.
  • Load the program into OpenSCAD.
  • Uncomment one of the sample functions, z(x,y)= and the corresponding 3dplot() call.
  • Render; using F5 to get a look-see is reasonably fast.
    • Note that when using math plotting software, the software often rescales the Z-axis for you, causing its range to be exaggerated or diminished relative to the X and Y axes. Since you're dealing with physical sized models here, that's left up to you. So, if you 3D 3D surface looks quite flat, you probably just need to multiply the Z values by some value like 5. Just change the Z function to add that multiplier. (While you could use OpenSCAD's scale() operator, that has the effect of also enlarging the skirt which you may not want.) I did find that going much beyond a 50x50 grid would cause trauma for OpenSCAD (2012.04.04). I also managed to cause it to core once or twice. So, please be gentle with OpenSCAD. And if I'm doing something stupid, do let me know.

comments.text: Nice work! I'm curious, is there any kind of resolution variable I can use to get a more refined mesh? Thanks!

comments.text: The grid tuple which defaults to [50,50].  (I.e., a 50 x 50 mesh.)

The second in the encounters series, this is a shrine to fire. We have both a cut stone and rough stone versions. The elemental symbol is inspired by the elemental symbols from Avatar: Last Airbender.

In this release we have:

  • Walls with the fire rune
  • Floors with the fire rune
  • Pillars that say "Fire" in runic futhark
  • A gothic archway
  • An alter to fire that can take walmart led votive candles

To find the diagonal and curved pieces, you can get them in:

  • Cut Stone: diagonal, curved, straight
  • Rough Stone: diagonal, curved, straight

The flames of the alter are made with a hot glue gun, after painting and after insertion of the candle. The alter has a floor piece to sink it into the ground (because it's kind of tall), or you can use it as scatter terrain. The runes on the base of the alter also say "fire" in elder futhark.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

Other Encounters

description.text:
First off, this is still a work in progress. This is a mount for all you people who like to keep the cables and stuff out of sight. This is also good for mounting it in sight, if that's your thing.
In short; a mount for your One Connect HDMI, USB and other interfaces. Mount it to the wall, inside your cabinet or under a shelf. We first designed it to use small nails for attaching it to our surface, but later also made versions with bigger holes and without holes. If you need a version that's not uploaded, ask and we will look for/create one.

There seems to be a lot of versions of the One Connect. This version is for the SOC1000M, the One Connect sold with the Samsung QE65Q7F (QE65Q7FAMTXXU). This mean that this has the inner dimensions 366 x 118 x 36mm.

If you have one of the smaller (mini) versions this is what you are looking for.

description.text:
I recommend to use 4mm plywood for the bottom and 10mm plywood for lateral parts. The given svg and dxf use these sizes.

There is also a tray generator that is an OpenSCAD script that will let you change the different dimensions of the object. The generator provides a vector file for a laser cutter, which is commonly found in a fablab.

Because I use a french version of the BSD, I cannot upload my files on Thingiverse (only the svg and the dxf with default dimensions). The project is fully open source and can be downloaded here [fr] https://gitlab.com/influencepc/generateur-de-plateau-de-service

You can also find explanations on the project here [fr] http://influence-pc.fr/18-08-2017-un-generateur-de-plateau-a-la-decoupe-laser

The tray can be made in medium or plywood. In addition, you can use transparent acrylic (PMMA, or Plexiglas) to cut the "protection" to put at the bottom. I thought it could be useful for those who would print pictures and display them under a protection.

print_settings.Notes:: Print however you like, really - the above settings are what I used, but it doesn't really matter.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
This is an OpenSCAD crafting of a spool holder very much along the lines of dagoma's inspired design. Easily tweaked for the size you'd like by changing parameter values and re-rendering.

Noticeable differences from the original are the pre-formed countersunk screw holes for attaching to things, and the top of the axle is a cone rather than spheroid.

Provided here are STL files for the two independent parts, and also versions with adjacent discard-able towers (these make for a more reliable print when the layers are small).

Note that if you increase $fn, be prepared to wait a long time for the wheel to render! I recommend switching off "Automatic Reload and Preview" if you go high on $fn...

See the source file simple_holder.scad for more commentary and details.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20% Triangles

Notes:

Print however you like, really - the above settings are what I used, but it doesn't really matter.

This design took quite a while to write; my objective in writing it (beyond doing a highly parameter-ised design) was to figure out ways of doing neat curved rounds and fillets in OpenSCAD for something more complex than trivial cases.

My method here works (I call it "sweeping sausages"), although I'm sure it can be much improved upon - the wheel takes a long time to preview, let alone render.

It's left as an exercise for the reader to figure out how it gets the job done :-)

description.text:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x7L9hMWy1BY Guide :
http://learn.adafruit.com/3d-printed-google-glass-adapter Upgrade your google glass with your own frames using a 3d printed adapter. A new pair of google glass frames will set you back about 200 bucks, but we can 3d print an adapter for under 1 dollar in material. A 3d printed plastic adapter turns any frame into prescription google glasses. Using a T5 screwdriver, we can easily detach the frames from glass. Just remove this one screw next to the eye sensor. It's right below the picture button. Every frame is different, so you'll need to measure two areas for a custom fit. Just edit the 123D file, adjust the wall size to fit your frames and print!

title: An Eye Piece Inspired by the Movie Suicide Squad
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
PLEASE READ >>>>>>>>>THIS IS STRICTLY A MODEL>>>>>>>IF YOU CHOOSE TO WEAR THIS, IT WILL BE AT YOUR OWN RISK!!!!!!!!!!!

An Eye Piece Inspired by the Movie Suicide Squad

I was impressed with some of the technology seen in the movie Suicide Squad

Based strictly off drawing and images on the Internet, I have made one of these for myself.

Print at .15 or finer.
25 - 50 Percent Infill
Speed (SLOW) 25 to 30

Print 2 sets of the The Eye Assembly Pins. Glue the longer pins into the Mechanical assembly with pin towards the inside of the eye piece. The shorter pins are to be glued too, but are not functional.

Some of the pieces are rather small, so take your time.

The piece was designed so that head band can be worn around the top of the head or the back of the head.

Please READ!!!!
The head band was made for me, so you may need to adjust yours to fit you.
Measure it before printing. Ues ABS on Head Band for flexibility

The Focus Blade, needs to be printed with as clear of material as possible. Or like I did, print, and swivel it down. This is the reason for the pin on it.

The Ear Assembly also pivots to allow you to set the lense to a comfortable position before gluing.

Please contact me if there needs to be corrections made.

This is as with many of the items posted ....A work In Progress

title: Tevo Tarantula Large Bed Glass Tensioner

description.text:
This is a Glass (or Mirror) tensioner for the Tevo Tarantula Large Bed.

Rev 2 on 8/25/2017 - I have revised the positioner and the back left bracket. They work much better now if you need to tighten the glass a larger distance. But I haven't had the time to update the F3D file yet.

I am not 100% sure that all beds are machined the same, so I have included the F3D file so you can modify it if you wish.

You will need two M3 12 bolts and two M3 nuts for the Adjustable corner.
This isn't really a remix, but rather a redo, as I started the design from scratch, but utilized ideas in the remixes that I have attributed here.

author: Skyrise

description.text: My ToM was making a lot of noise from the filament vibrating, enough that it bothered me. I came up with this simple hack that solves that problem. My ToM has been much quieter since, with no noticeable effect to print quality

Ignore the STL, it wouldn't let me publish this without one.
  • Cut rubber band into rubber string.
  • Tie it down to the sides of your bot so it's putting tension on the filament.
  • Print
    • The rubber band absorbs the vibrations that would otherwise travel up the filament and vibrate against the spool.

author: antonio65

title: Coolice Hypercube Evolution Dual Z Linear Rail Bracket Left & Right

description.text:
Hey All.

I've just made a simple modification to these Hypercube Evolution Dual Linear Rail Brackets.
Bascially when using the usual M5 X 12mm long screws, the screw head is quite difficult to get to as it's recessed low inside the print. So once the 3030 Y beams are in place, I found it difficult to get even a ball ended allen key down to them.
So what I have done is rasied the recessed screw head landing pad which brings the head up nearer the top of the part so is more easily accessable.
It will require the use of M5 X 35mm long button head screws to use.

Ian

It is a good idea. I had the same problem.
If you want to make it perfect you could change the knurls to M3 nuts?

print_settings.Notes:: I'd avoid printing with supports. Print it face down (slopes side facing up), and it should print fine without them, even with PETG.

description.text:
This is a replacement leadscrew bracket for the buildplate frame on the D-Bot that fits the larger 20mm alti-backlash nuts for the ACME threaded rods. These include the ones that come with the hardware kit being sold on Aliexpress. (Its a fairly standard size nut, the collar is 20mm high and 20mm in diameter, with two mounting holes 28mm apart...)

This does necessarily move the axis out slightly, which may require either modifying the T brackets holding the Z-motor rail to the side rails, or moving the bed support brackets from the inside of the rails to the outside.

The nut mounts to the bracket using two M4 screws, anything 8mm or above should be fine. The threaded holes are 9mm deep, so a 12mm should fit, but barely. Worst case, use a washer.

This also has an opening on the rear for an M4 nut and an opening on the top, which can be used for a center mount on a heavier build plate. I'm not using them on mine right now, but I wanted the option. These are 6mm offset from the rail, to match my M4 replacement brackets here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2489263

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Infill probably isn't super critical above maybe 40%... the supports are pretty beefy and the weight is held on the heftiest part of it.

I'd avoid printing with supports. Print it face down (slopes side facing up), and it should print fine without them, even with PETG.

A casing for your WeMos D1 Mini and a HC-SR501 Infrared PIR Motion Sensor.
The WeMos_D1_Mini_HC-SR501_433Mhz_Transmitter is 9mm longer so it can house a 433MHz transmitter.

The WeMos D1 Mini uses the PIR to detect motion and sends a message over my MQTT broker I run. At the same time the WeMos is capable of receiving instructions from MQTT to switch on the lights in my room by transmitting the KlikAanKlikUit protocol over 433MHz.
This way can place my casings strategically and control the lights.
With the combination of MQTT and Node Red, the possibilities are endless!

I love to see your version of this casing !

HyperCube

No

No

i created this by fusing 4 isospheres with differing numbers of triangles, and adjusting all the spheres until every sphere has a small amount of faces protruding from the surface.

this isoISOiso ball can be used to determine precisely how well your printer can handle small details. with high end printers, you should be able to see the smallest faces and edges without an issue. and if you give this a 50 percent infill using flexible filament, it would make a great bouncy ball!

description.text:
Remix of Tamas' Acoustic Guitar nut. Complete rewrite, avoiding Non Commercial issues in his design also.

Beyond the customizer options I added, the following was also changed:

  • String notches have rounded bottom for better fitment
  • Converted the small horizontal "lip" at the bottom to a vertical bevel of sorts

Mostly did this so I could punch in a few numbers and print a new one on a whim. Have a few guitars that need this treatment, so it made sense to share my results once they had been achieved.

Note on licensing

I had this set to CC BY-NC-SA from the onset to avoid issues with Tamas' thing. But as time has gone on, I have realized that despite this being my most frequently printed design, I am least happy with this design out of every other one I have published. I do not feel that a "Non Commercial" license is in the spirit of this site, which is basically a 3D printer's GitHub. Frankly, I'm surprised it's even an option to select "Non Commercial" licenses at all.

Given that I rewrote this entire thing from scratch to fufill a need (my 5 string bass actually), I am the creator of this thing. Rather than simply tweaking Tamas' thing, I very literally reverse engineered the relevant bits and made it the right way. This is fairly obvious if you compare the two side by side in OpenSCAD -- output is the same, but the code is vastly different. It is with all that in mind that I am relicensing this as BSD. What that means for you is that this print is way, WAY more open than it has been, and will remain this way. No more figuring out what constitutes commercial use, just use it however you damn well please.

Changelog

2018-02-03

  • BSD license (formerly CC BY-NC-SA)

2017-10-17

  • No changes, just more pics. Showcasing a 5 string bass to show the Customizer's versatility.

2017-08-22

  • Added string angle and nut depth parameters after a test print needed these tweaks to fit properly

2017-08-18

  • Initial upload

Printer:

M3D Micro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100% if possible

Notes:

Any rigid filament would work. I'll be using PLA or ABS, as long as it isn't a flexible material, you'll be fine. The higher the infill, the better support it will provide, and the easier it will be to file down later if need be (recommend 100% infill given the small size of this part).

Don't know if a heated bed is necessary, but wouldn't hurt. Avoid rafts and brims to cut down on post-processing work when finished. I doubt they're needed anyways.

title: Titan Aero 27mm Piezo Z probe Bracket

description.text:
Mount for Titan Aero with a 27mm Piezo sensor from https://www.precisionpiezo.co.uk/ . Does not need a drilled sensor.

The design is tested on 60mm/s with 160mm/s movement speed on a 3dbenchy without showing any visible "wobble" due to the lesser strenght for the piezo to be triggered.While probing I get a deviation of 0.003mm (from Z-0.098 to Z-0.101) when probing the same spot on and on.

It is designed to fit my Flashforge creator pro but it will fit other mounts with this style of clamping aswell. Let me know if you need small changes to the design and I'll upload that.

Ideas came from the part I remixed that Moriquendi made so all credit goes there.

Video of the mount in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Emi0pRuY6gU

titan_aero_holder.stl - First version, more solid
totan_aero_holder_v5.stl - Second version, designed to put more force on piezo disk. (doubt it's really needed)

comments.text: Pardon my ignorance but I how do these work. I understand the one that fits to the top of the groove mount, the pressure from the nozzle touching the bed, squashes the piezo which produces a voltage. How do they work when the piezo is mounted to the titan bracket?
comments.author: totalitarian

comments.text: From what I understood, the pressure on the nozzle is transmit to the motor. Then the motor move and so the piezo generate a small voltage, as you said.
comments.author: totalitarian

comments.text: Sorry I missed this question. It works by detecting movement on the nozzle tip. It takes almost no pressure to trigger it since it's super sensitive. I've adjusted the sensitivity down by a lot to not trigger by Z axis movement or me walking on the floor besides the printer and it still triggers perfectly when probing on PEI.

title: Elongated E3D V6 Fan shroud for Duet Smart Effector And 30mm Blower (radial) Fan Mounts

description.text:
If like me you have the Duet3D Smart Effector and are using a more powerful 30mm hotend fan than the e3d supplied unit for example a Sunon Maglev, you might find due to the compact size of the Smart effector assembly, the fan's coils are inducing a current in the nozzle contact sensor of the effector resulting in erratic performance with the hotend fan on.

The solution is to move the fan outwards by 10mm or so placing it just outside the area containing the strain gauge PCB traces on the effector.

Based on the official E3D V6 fan shroud, this one has a 10mm extension. Drill out the holes to 2.7-2.8mm before screwing in the fan. Fits snuggly on my hotend but I included two holes for a cable tie if you want to use one also.

I have also included radial/blower fan mounts for Sunon 5v 0.68W 30mm blower fans, attach these to the ball stud m3 screws with nuts and bond the fans onto then with superglue.

Notes:

ABS preferred print as orientated to avoid layer delamination when attaching the shroud.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Nice, sturdy 6" hex-shaped dice tray/box. Please do not use as a weapon of mal-intent. The provided template will cut two blank-faced trays which you may choose to embellish with other cutting or etching patterns (or not) to create customized dice boxes, It is designed with a minimum 0.5" safety margin around the edge of the frame. The inner liner of the top cover can also be used as a template to cut any felt or other material that you might wish to line the bottom of the tray. I may be providing some with patterns in the near future.

Like the Viking themed tray that I just published at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2583384

Formatted for cutting on 6mm MDF cut to (Arch C) 24" x 18" sheet size specs, which fits across the bed of an Epilog Helix. All my patterns are designed for 300dpi. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

print_settings.Notes:: The base of the bowl has extreme overhangs, that most people will need supports to handle. I used 3 or 4 processes in this print; very thin (0.1) layers for the bottom 4 layers, then thicker (0.2) for the next 9mm, and finally 0.3mm after that. The fan was left on for the duration of the print to bring about an opaque, foamy look to the end result. Up to 9mm (the completion of the internal base of the bowl, I used a 15mm infill, and after that 0% infill.

title: Stencil for bleaching/spray painting eclipse logos

description.text:
This is a stencil I used to make eclipse t-shirts for Tennesee eclipse viewing parties. I uploaded a version without the 3 stars of TN. It's 2 layers thick. Its designed for the larger format CR-10 with 300mm bed so you might need to scale it down for smaller printers. Tested Gcode included. You can spray bleach on darker shirts or spraypaint on light/white shirts. Or just spraypaint a logo on the wall!

For shirts you'll want to use cardboard to catch overspray as pictured. Spray the back of the stencil with a temporary adhesive to get a nice sharp transfer (available in hobby or fabric stores).

2mm+ shells.

A "mechanical" keyboard faceplate for the PocketCHIP.

Keys are held in place with straitened paperclips that are 1mm in diameter. This gives the keys a pivot point and reduces the amount of force needed to press each button.

Assembling only requires straitening paperclips and threading them through the holes in the case and keys.

A full print would require:

1x face plate
1x dpad
2x spacebar keys
2x backspace/enter keys
48x standard keys

I would print a few extras in case of print errors or breaks during assembly. You also may want an extra backspace/enter type key for the "P" key on the PocketCHIP. My faceplate doesn't lay completely flat and the standard key doesn't have the same click feel of the others as it's slightly higher than the rest. Using the backspace/enter key lets it reach the PCB switch dome. YMMV.

The Fusion 360 design (my first) can be found here: http://a360.co/2w4sP3R

The idea for the keys came from the HP-35s keyboard. I plan on adding some nice color-coded vinyl sticker labels similar to the WP 34S Overlay

Faceplate is based on the PocketCHIP Keyboard Faceplate by vjapolitzer

Forum thread

V2: 2017-09-14 Added face_switch_plate_row2_through_hole.stl which makes the row 2 paperclip hole bore through to the d-pad.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hziY0q2drz6

comments.text: I printed this in ABS and set a scale factor of 1.077 in order to get the actual 135mm outside diameter. I removed a small square pad in the Meade filter and put the pad in the inside diameter of the adapter. The inside diameter should fit the lens shade that came with the Sigma lens and the outside diameter should fit a bit snug on the Meade 530 filter housing.

Glossary:
FullKit
Files marked FULLKIT at the beginning are all the pieces you need to assembly for a full base tiles/corner tile/wall tiles etc... They usually include the base, basecap, floor, floorcap, and walls with wallcap if applicable.
Kit
Files marked KIT at the beginning are the pieces you need to assembly a full tile without the base pieces (because there is a base kit, this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2463765)
KITDUAL
The is the same as a kit, but a files that contains two copies of the part. Cut down on copy paste in slicers.
Something else
These are the individual pieces if you wish to print a single part of the tile. Not all the files are done for these, and you may have to pull them out of the kits. (working on this)

description.text:
This filter lets you take pictures of the sun with any smartphone. Couldn't find solar glasses? Just print this thing so that you can still watch the eclipse.

Parts List:
1 filter body (the 3D printed part)
3 small rubber bands: http://amzn.to/2vR2sOW
2 2" square pieces of mylar. http://amzn.to/2vLA16x

You can check out my video about it here: https://youtu.be/5Bvtpxah8sA

Assembly instructions:

1) Cut the mylar into small circles, just larger than the filter.
2) Strech both layers of the mylar over the filter as tight as you can, and hold it in place with one of the rubber bands. Depending on the size of the rubber band you will probably need to double it over so that it's tighter. Any wrinkles will hurt the quality of your photos.
3) tie the remaining to rubber bands onto two of the slots on the filter, then tie the rubbers bands together.

Use instructions:

Loop the rubber bands over your phone and position the filter so that it is directly over your lens. Use a camera app that lets you manually control your camera settings. zoom in as far as you can with your optical zoom, set the focus to infinity, set the ISO as low as possible, and adjust the shutter speed until you can see the sun clearly.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Notes:

Print settings are unimportant, however, it was designed for .4mm extrusion width, and .3mm layer height. Remove from print surface carefully, as the base ring is someone delicate.

description.text: The HotHardWare logo written on a plate.
Most 3d printers will be able to print this piece.

A foot pedal with a few extras.
  • USB interface. Defaults to "CTRL-C"
  • Adjustable spring tension
  • Adjustable height switch
  • Analogue potentiometer
  • Force/Haptic feedback with rumble
  • Daisy chainable
  • Configurable keypresses on push AND release
    (e.g. You can end CTRL-C on press, and CTRL-V on release)
  • Powered by Teensy 3
    • This is a pretty simple foot pedal with a switch and analogue feedback. It connects to USB and emulated a HID keyboard.

You will need:
===========
  • Some screws (TODO exactly what!)
  • A cocktail stick
  • A clothes peg
  • Super Glue
  • A "standard" size microswitch
  • A potentiometer
  • A Teensy 3.x dev kit
  • Soldering iron + solder
  • Wire
    • What to do
    ========
    Print all of the parts with 0.3mm layer and 20% infill. 1) Glue the pedal top plate to the bottom plate
    2) Take the spring out of the peg. Give it a good unwinding to it is V shaped
    3) Snap the cocktail stick to 25mm.
    4) Put the spring in the underrside of the pedal and push the cockstail stick through the hole.
    5) Glue the curved pot gear onto the pedal.
    6) Take the base, and insert the potentiometer into the holder.
    7) Screw the potentiometer into the holder and attach its large nut.
    8) Slide the pot cog over the pot and glue in place. Before gluing make sure it will align with the pedal
    9) attach the microswitch to the base using 2 screws
    10) put a screw through the bottom of the base into the spring tensioner. Once it comes out through the top, place the pot cap on there
    11) insert the optional rumble pack into the pedal bottom. Remember to peel the self adhesive tape
    12) Solder all of the pots, switches leds and rumble packs to the Teensy. Make sure the Teensy is located correctly
    13) screw the pedal into the the base
    14) glue the front panel onto the base
    15) atach the back panel with two M2 screws. Software
    =======
  • Download the software from the Git Tree
    https://github.com/ginge/footpedal
  • Customise the keypresses
  • Flash the Teensy
  • optionally build the QT5 app to configure the pedal

comments.text:
Printed in PETG. Only modifications were adding more structure behind curved pot gear and tapping bigger holes for M5 bolts. I used a keyboard USB interface vice teensy.
It's not a perfect fix, the pot gears keep slipping, but I'll figure something out.

description.text:
My friend and I are making an SLA printer and I thought I would share what we have so far with the internet. Once it's done (and if it works) then I'll go more in depth and make some better instructions, we might also make an assembly video or something.
At the moment we are waiting for some of the components to arrive, you don't need to get the exact ones below, eg you could get longer linear shafts and a longer lead screw if you want.
I am happy to answer any comments and If you could point out flaws in the design it would be much appreciated because I'm only 14 and me and my friend are sort of just pulling random designs out of our heads and not doing much research.
Thanks

UPDATE:
Instead of doing all of the wiring by hand, I found this handy chip that makes the wiring much more simple.

A49888 extension board:

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/3D-Printer-A4988-DRV8825-Stepper-Motor-Control-Board-Expansion-Board/32505771845.html?

9V power supply for it:

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1pc-New-Waterproof-DC-DC-Converter-12V-Step-Down-to-9V-3A-15W-Power-Supply-Module/32672888599.html?

Attach the lead screw to the NEMA 17 using the coupler, then bring the lead screw under the ‘Middle Face’ and put it through the biggest hole, Use the spacers and screws to attach the Nema 17 to it. Put the linear bearings into the Build Platform by screwing, with spacers, the LM6UU Holder onto the Build Platform with the bearing in between them and also attach the nut that comes with the lead screw.

Secure the ‘Linear Holder’s onto the bottom of the ‘Middle Face’ on either side of the lead screw using nuts and bolts, then you can shove the bottoms of the linear shafts into them, slide the linear bearings onto the linear shafts and twist the lead screw to lower the platform, put the ‘Top Part’ onto the tops of the linear shafts and have the top of the lead screw in the middle hole of it.

Plug the stepper motor into the driver and then the driver and limit switch into the pi using (almost) any free pins (this is set in nano DLP). Now you can install nano DLP onto the pi, make sure everything is working before setting up the rest of the printer then unplug it all.
(I will go more in-depth into the wiring and software once it's done)

Get the screen and you should be able to peel the glass/metal part off the PCB part of it because it's only held in by some double sided tape, don't break the cables though. Once you have done that you will find the aluminium part on the back of the screen, it wraps around the side of the glass and you can bend back the sides of it and take it off along with the white plastic, now there will be a bunch of plastic lenses and stuff, take them off and cut the wires leading to the LED strip and peel it off so you are left with just the LCD and touch screen part attached to the PCB.

Solder the UV LED's to the PCB in the config shown in one of the pictures, secure the LED panel onto the ‘bottom part’ with screws and spacers then attach the LCD panel above it with the brackets. Plug the LCD into the raspberry pi using an HDMI cable.

Attach the Raspberry Pi to the 'Bottom Part' using spacers and screws, then connect everything to the pi except the stepper motor and limit switch. Then you can put the ‘Walls’ onto the bottom part and connect them with glue. For power, put the 2.5mm female power input into the hole in the back then wire it to the button and split it four ways, one going to the step-down converter then raspberry pi, the other three going to the lights, the screen and the stepper motor controller. Put the ‘Middle face’ onto the top of the walls after plugging in the stepper motor and limit switch. Finally, you can put the vat in and plug in the printer, and it's done.

These instructions are still under development so some parts might not make sense.

title: M3 screw mount for Airtripper v3

description.text:
The design of the Airtripper v3 extruder has mounting holes that are oversized for an M3 screw.  
This is an adapter that fits into the mounting holes of the extruder and is able to accept an M3 screw.  
Additionally, I also designed it to mount the extruder ninety degrees from normal as this allows me to run the Bowden tube better for my Kossel.

Printed with three shells and and 50% infill. This is probably overkill for this part.  
Your mileage may vary.

author: Deerslayer_1

description.text:
After putting a Motley v3 510 on my mod, I realized I really didn't like the stock collar. So I measured it out and made my own. This is the result. Scaled 1.05 larger than stock to account for some PLA shrinkage. Enjoy and feel free to remix~.

--

"Fire Girl Collar" was designed for box mods that have at least 50mm of length off the center of the 510 with the vents in an "X" pattern. Shorter than 50mm and it will overhang. Can be printed well with as much as a 0.5mm nozzle with FDM printers

"Fire Girl Collar Small" was designed for box mods that have at least 40mm of length off the center of the 510 with the vents in an "X" pattern. Shorter than 40mm and it will overhang. A 0.4mm nozzle would probably work best for this print with FDM printers

"Iron Cross Collar" was inspired by a friend of mine who is a U.S. Marine with a great love of German tanks. It fits in the same area as the "Fire Girl Collar Small" and should print well with as big as a 0.5 nozzle.

--

Updated 9/21/17 to fix a mesh error.
Updated 9/26/17 to add Iron Cross collar.

title: Mini Rotary Tool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple rotary tool I decided to build after finding a motor that came with a tool chuck. It's really easy to make, and does a great job cutting, sanding, and polishing (sort of) 3d prints.

When printing, make sure the resolution is high enough for the threads to work. My printer allows threads to work up to 0.15mm layer heights, but no thicker. Remember, different printers have different tolerances.

Parts:
-Motor with chuck and key (http://amzn.to/2wapSBi)
-12v plug with female socket (http://amzn.to/2waW1Zw)
-or without 12v plug if you already have one (http://amzn.to/2waWtaa)

-Rotary tool kit (any will work, but here's one I found) (http://amzn.to/2iedmuR)

From Wikipedia: "The East Van Cross is a symbol formed by the words East written vertically and Van written horizontally in capital letters, intersecting at the shared letter A, and forming the shape of a cross. Van is short for Vancouver, and the reference is to the city’s Eastern half, traditionally less wealthy and harder-edged.

The East Van Cross traditionally was the work of graffiti artists, said to express the “marginality and defiance” of East Vancouver.

Starting in the 21st century, the symbol has been adopted as a city icon, most visibly expressed in the form of Monument for East Vancouver by artist Ken Lum, erected in 2010.It has become possible to purchase clothing[4] and jewelry bearing the East Van Cross motif."

title: Telescope Solar Projector | Solulus
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Solulus (Latin for "Little Sun") is a device that you can attach to your telescope's eyepiece to turn it into a solar projector. I have uploaded versions of the device to fit around the barrel of the most common telescope eyepiece sizes. Refer to the instructions section below to learn how to assemble and use it. Enjoy!

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

5%

How Do I Assemble This?

This device only involves one 3D-printable part, called a barrel mount. You need to choose the correct barrel mount part to fit the barrel of your eyepiece. If you are accustomed to the metric system and you have a 3.175 cm eyepiece, print the 1.25 inch model. Print the 2 inch model if you use a 5.08 cm eyepiece, and the 0.965 inch model if you use a 2.4511 cm eyepiece. Other than the 3D-printed part, you will need:

  • One wire coat hanger
  • Six sheets of cardstock paper (or two sheets of paper and cardboard)
  • Pliers
  • Wire Cutters
  • Scissors
  • The PDF files included with the STL files
  • A glue stick
  • Access to a 2D printer

After you have collected all of your parts, follow the instructions below to assemble your projector.

  1. Print one of each of the two PDF files on separate sheets of cardstock. These files are called "projector-shield.pdf" and "projector-screen.pdf."
  2. Glue all six sheets of cardstock into two three-sheet-thick sheets. Alternatively, glue the printed paper onto sheets of cardboard. Keep the printed sheets on the tops of each stack. These stacks will become the projector shield and projector screen parts.
  3. While you let the glue dry, straighten the coat hanger and cut it into three sections of equal length. Form one end of each of the sections into a "U" shape.
  4. Cut along the lines on each of the paper stacks. Be sure to read the directions in the "projector-shield.pdf" file to ensure that you cut the correct inner circle. With a sharp tool, poke or drill out the dots on the projector screen.
  5. Slide the wire coat hanger sections through the 3D-printed barrel mount flat-side-first. The two sides of the "U" shape on each hanger section, which you created earlier, should fit through the two holes on one of the three prongs of the barrel mount.
  6. Feed the other end of the wire coat hanger sections through the holes in the screen, which you just created.
  7. Bend the ends of the coat hanger sections to stop the screen from falling off of the rest of the device.
  8. Slide the barrel mount part around the barrel of your eyepiece, keeping the beveled side facing the end of the eyepiece through which you would look. Slide the projector shield behind the barrel mount part.
  9. Fasten your eyepiece, which is now supporting the entire Solulus assembly, to your telescope.
  10. If necessary, bend the wire coat hangers to make the projector screen perpendicular to the barrel of your telescope.

How Do I Use This?

This device allows you to observe the sun without using special eye protection. When you aim your telescope at the sun, use common sense. Do not look through the eyepiece or towards the sun, but instead observe the telescope's shadow on the projector shield. Rotate the telescope against the direction the telescope's shadow looks to be facing, and you will soon see the sun's projection on the makeshift screen. Keep in mind that parts of your eyepieces may melt if they are made from plastic.

title: Wilson II - Hypercube X Carriage, Remix (OCD compliant)

description.text:
Updated 22 January 2018-
New version added (for Wilson IIK build) re-posted here. Belt alignment and lock gaps adjusted. Pictures are from previous version.
See the Wilson IIk here;
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2765853

Update 25 August 2017-
I am specifically restricting use for Shiv Integer. You are NOT allowed to use my design in your "Art" pieces. Thank you.

I really like the Hypercube's design for their Extruder https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1752766 But the holes didn't line up with the carriage from the Wilson II. So I made a new one.

I like connectors and hate having to reroute wire when something needs swapping out so I came up with this design that should make those (of us) with wire management "issues" (you know who you are) extremely happy.

The idea is to take half a 20x80mm prototyping board and mount some connectors to it to make swapping modules at the hotend easier. There's also a mount for a wire loom to be ziptied to the back. Loop-back connectors make belt runs easy, because the belt meshes with itself, zip ties are not needed.

I'm just about to start my final build for my second Wilson II that will incorporate this design (and other mods as well) so I'll have pictures of it in place shortly.

author: faisyl

description.text:
The LCD (20 characters by 4 rows) has been mounted inside an alloy box. I needed a spacer so the LCD frame would be flush with the exterior of the alloy box (2 mm thick) and also wanted a way to mount the LCD as unobtrusively as possible.

By printing the spacer (complete with indentation for header pins) with holes for the LCD mounting holes, and chassis mounting holes that were outside the LCD PCB, I was able to use small self tapping screws to first mount the LCD PCB to the spacer. I could then cut the aperture in the lid of the box for the LCD to poke through. Because the chassis holes for the spacer mount were still accessible, I could then drill four small pilot holes for the mounting holes to mark their positions. These were then enlarged for the screws. This allowed the LCD to be mounted only using small screws and for the mounts also to be drilled easily.

The project is an Arduino Uno+GPS/SD card+Temp sensor to measure water temperature along a 22.8km lake. http://www.laketyersbeach.net.au/laketempprofile.html

They fit nice on the first try so I figured I would share. I made two versions, one with feet left and right and one with one set of feet so if you have a smaller spool they'll sit closer together. The double feet ones work great on a 1kg spool. I printing these at two different settings 0.4 and 20% and 30% infill and I couldn't tell the difference, so if you want to save filament go with 20%

title: Camera and Light boom for 3D printer

description.text:
This project contains all the parts for an adjustable boom to position a camera and two LED lights to give an optimum view of your printer's build platform.

The USB cable for the camera passes down the inside of the boom. The magnetic clamp that holds the boom can also hold one or two USB-powered flexible LED lights.

No drilling of your printer or the parts is required.

In addition to the printed parts, you will need

  • A USB camera with wide-angle or fish-eye lens (eg this camera, or this cheaper camera )
  • Rare-earth disc magnets (eg. 15x1.5 magnets or stronger 15x5 magnets )
  • USB LED lamps (eg these lamps )
  • An M8 or 5/16 bolt and nut (you can print one!)
  • A dual-port USB charger and some USB extension cables
  • screws or hot glue to hold the camera
  • better colour-coordination taste than me

author: jwerry

description.text:
A simple calibration for fine-tuning your three extruders offsets.  
On the Y-axis: The distance from the first extrude bottom edge there should be 10 mm to the second extrude bottom edge. And to the third there should be 20 mm.  
On the Z-axis: The distance from the first extrude left edge there should be 10 mm to the second extrude left edge. And to the third there should be 20 mm.  
Print one layer or more, pause, measure, adjust offset, save and restart print until you have a perfect offset.

description.text: This is a mount that allows you to have an XT60 side mount without having to use a PDB. This mount is MUCH more secure and wont tear away like the PDB XT60 mount does even with the rubber guards. Using longer M2 bolts down through the top plate secures the mount and I also use longer M3 bolts up through the FC to secure the front.

Magnetic mount for an Amazon Echo Dot* for mounting it on vertical magnetic surfaces (or if you just want to change the color or shape of the dot). Uses 5mm x 10mm magnets* (four will be enough for most magnetic surfaces, but you can use up to 12). The dot is inserted from the top.

Filaments: Atomic Clear and Silver PLA, Fillamentum Vertigo Gray* PLA

remixed_from.author: juholga
remixed_from.title: PokeSpinner - The Pokeball Fidget Spinner for B127/608

description.text:
This is a tray that fits the box and can hold a pokeball fidget spinner. Check out the original model (2459802) for the rest of the files (Middle black part and button).

You need to print two trays, two caps, a middle frame, and the button to create one spinner box.

The original model was for wide version of the pokeball spinner. This tray can fit the non-wide version. Use the body part "PokeSpinner_Body_oma.STL" or "PokeSpinner_Body_oma_lasipallolle.STL" from the thing item 2430831. Then spinner will fit to the tray.

I also created an additional cap that has a hidden inner tray in it. This combined with the tray creates a tiny container for small items.
